But what are $\vert x-2\vert$ and $\vert x-4\vert$? %
%text \textbf{Right or wrong?} Given the definitions of $\vert x\vert,\vert x-2\vert$ and $\vert x-4\vert$, the table below correctly summarizes the value of $f(x)$ in various intervals. %
step.tex:
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline & x \lt 0 & x\in(0,2) & x\in (2,4) & x\gt 4 \\ \hline \vert x\vert & -x & x & x & x \\ \hline \vert x-2\vert & 2-x & 2-x & x-2 & x-2 \\ \hline \vert x-4\vert & 4-x & 4-x & 4-x & x-4 \\ \hline f(x) & 6-3x & 6-x & x+2 & 3x -6 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\
\texttt{Note: } f(x) = \vert x\vert + \vert x-2\vert + \vert x-4\vert

%text There are three critical points in this question, $x =0,2$ and $4$. These are critical because the definition of $\vert x-a\vert$ changes at these points.
With 3 critical points, we have 4 intervals to consider, namely, $x\lt 0, \underbrace{0\leq x\lt 2}_{x\in(0,2)}, \underbrace{2\leq x\lt 4}_{x\in (2,4)}$ and $x\gt 4$. The table simply shows the values of $\vert x\vert$, $\vert x-2\vert$ and $\vert x-4\vert$ in these intervals.
And $f(x) = \vert x\vert + \vert x-2\vert + \vert x-4\vert$ has been evaluated separately in each interval. %

step.reason: \begin{align} A &= \int_0^4 f(x)\cdot dx \\ &= \underbrace{\int_0^2 (6-x)\cdot dx}_{f(x) = 6-x} + \underbrace{\int_2^4 (x+2)\cdot dx}_{f(x) = x+2} \\ &= \left[ 6x -\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^2 + \left[ \frac{x^2}{2} + 2x\right]_2^4 \\ &= (12 - 2) + [(8+8)-(2+4)] = 20 \end{align}
